journal-title-group.journal-title: American journal of obstetrics and gynecology

title-group.article-title: Perioperative Opioid Dispensing and Persistent Use after Benign Hysterectomy: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis

article-meta.aff: 1.Maternal Fetal Care Center, Boston Children’s Hospital, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA
2.Department of Surgery, Baylor College of Medicine, Houston, TX
3.Department of Gynecology and Obstetrics, Johns Hopkins, Baltimore, MD.
4.Department of Obstetrics, Gynecology and Reproductive Sciences, Yale School of Medicine, New Haven, CT.
5.Department of International Health, Johns Hopkins School of Public Health, Baltimore, MD

fn.p: MB and KH conceived the study aims and design, KH, JW and SA contributed to the data extraction, planned the analysis, interpreted the results and drafted the final version of the paper. KH, EG and JW contributed to data extraction and carried out the statistical analysis. AA, AF and MB contributed to the interpretation of findings and manuscript writing. All authors contributed to the revision of the manuscript. AA and MB who authored one of the included studies have not been involved in the selection or assessment of studies.

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Mostafa A. Borahay: Department of Gynecology and Obstetrics, Johns Hopkins University, 4940 Eastern Ave, Baltimore, MD 21224-2780, Phone: (410) 550-0337, mboraha1@jhmi.edu

fn.p: Conflict of interest: None to declare.

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: This meta-analysis was conducted to 1) assess the quantity and dose of perioperatively dispensed opioids for benign hysterectomy by procedure route and 2) identify the predictors of persistent opioid use after the procedure

sec.title: Data sources:
sec.p: PubMed, Web of Science and Embase were systematically searched up to 25 March 2022.

sec.title: Study eligibility criteria:
sec.p: Studies reporting data on opioid dispensing among patients undergoing benign hysterectomy were considered eligible. The primary outcome was the dosage of opioids dispensed perioperatively (from 30 preoperative days to 21 postoperative days). The secondary outcome was the predictors of persistent opioid use after benign hysterectomy (from 3 months to 3 years postoperatively). Total opioid dispensing was measured in morphine milligram equivalents (MME) units.

sec.title: Study appraisal and synthesis methods:
sec.p: The random-effects model was used to pool the mean differences or odds ratios (ORs) and the corresponding 95% confidence intervals (CIs).

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Eight studies presenting data on 377,569 women undergoing benign hysterectomy were included. Of these women, 83% (95% CI: 81, 84) were dispensed opioids during the perioperative period. The average amount of perioperatively dispensed opioids was 143.5 MME (95% CI: 40, 247). Women undergoing vaginal hysterectomy were dispensed a significantly lower amount of opioids than those undergoing laparoscopic or abdominal hysterectomies. The overall rate of persistent opioid use after benign hysterectomy was 5% (95% CI: 2, 8). Younger patient age (OR 1.38 [95% CI: 1.17, 1.63]), smoking history (OR 1.87 [95% CI: 1.67, 2.10]), alcohol use (OR 3.16 [95% CI: 2.34, 4.27]), back pain (OR 1.50 [95% CI: 1.10, 2.05]) and fibromyalgia (OR 1.60 [95% CI: 1.39, 1.83]) were significantly associated with a higher risk of persistent opioid use after benign hysterectomy. However, there was no significant impact of hysterectomy route and operative complexity on persistent opioid use postoperatively.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Perioperative opioid dispensing is significantly dependent on the route of hysterectomy, with the lowest dispensed MME of opioids for vaginal hysterectomy and the highest for abdominal hysterectomy. Nevertheless, hysterectomy route did not significantly predict persistent opioid use postoperatively, whereas younger age, smoking, alcohol use, back pain and fibromyalgia were significantly associated with persistent opioid use.

list-item.p: Perioperative opioid dispensing is dependent on hysterectomy route, while postoperative persistent opioid use is associated with younger age, smoking, alcohol use, back pain and fibromyalgia.
